title: Why we'll need 4500 more consultants by 2021
text:
“Australia’s strong, mature economy has been posting big consulting growth numbers for several years now, and we see no sign of client spending slowing down any time soon," said BJ Richards of Source Global Research.

"We rate [Australian] clients among the most consulting-hungry in the world, and with very high revenues per consultant, filling that demand can be a highly profitable business.

BJ Richards of Source Global Research.

"Growth and digitisation remain high on the client agenda and will provide ample opportunities for ambitious consultants through 2020."

Ms Richards said the number of new consultants was based on data modelling that assumes that "all the new market growth will come from an increase in consultants".

"This assumption is not necessarily correct because some growth will come from automation and technology advances which are harder to predict. For the purposes of comparison, we are purely looking at how many more consultants will be required to fill the expected market increase," she said.

Australia has dropped behind Britain for clients' "propensity to buy" consulting services with the uncertainty caused by Brexit leading to a spike in demand in that part of the world.

"UK clients are already the most eager consulting buyers in the world, and as the seemingly interminable Brexit saga drags on, more and more of them are looking for help planning for what comes next," Ms Richards wrote in the report.

The research company's findings were not all upbeat for the local consulting industry. Ms Richards warned that slowing GDP growth could begin to hurt if businesses started to cut back on their advisory spend.

"Slowing GDP growth isn’t doing this market any favours ... While Australia’s robust consulting industry is well positioned to weather a slowdown, firms looking to grow may want to ask themselves if they’re prepared to be upping investment at a time when clients may very well be easing off the accelerator," she said.
description: The Australian consulting industry will need to find another 4500 staff over the next three years to keep pace with demand for services, a study finds.
